awd_titl_txt: High-dimensional probability in ergodic theory and statistical physics
awd_abstract_narration:
In mathematical probability theory, stationary stochastic processes model phenomena that reveal new, unpredictable outcomes as time passes, but whose underlying probability laws remain constant: consider, most simply, the repeated tossing of a coin.  Ergodic theory studies abstractly what kinds of randomness are possible in such a process, where two processes are regarded as equivalent if either can be obtained by a suitable encoding of the other.  However, many random phenomena of great importance in modern coding theory, statistics, and data science do not arise in the linear fashion that is dictated by the arrow of time in a stationary process.  Rather, they are structured according to a large underlying network, which may itself be highly disordered.  The current project seeks to adapt methods of ergodic theory to this new setting or understand why they fail and then develop replacements.  For models of randomness governed by underlying disordered networks, some of the main issues to be investigated include: (i) whether the broad statistical features scale in a simple way with the size of the network; (ii) whether the random behavior that is visible at a particular node of the network can be estimated easily from the parameters of the model; (iii) how one can determine effectively whether a given model of network randomness can be re-encoded in some simpler form, such as pure independent noise at each node.  All of these issues arise in the theoretical underpinnings of modern research in computer and data science and could serve as a guide towards new discoveries in those fields.  The pursuit of these questions requires background knowledge from diverse parts of probability and pure mathematics, and so the current project includes plans to develop educational materials and train graduate students in a novel but valuable mix of those disciplines.

The project has two more specific aims. The first is the further development of the methods in the principal investigator's recent proof of the weak Pinsker theorem in ergodic theory. This theorem asserts that any stationary ergodic process may be re-encoded, in the sense of measure-theoretic isomorphism, into a nearly deterministic component and a purely random component.  The methods from the proof apply to the joint distribution of a stationary sequence of random variables, deriving a structural description from some basic information-theoretic parameters of a joint distribution.  Such implications are still in their infancy, and the proposed project would explore a range of related parameters and their consequences. The second aim concerns the broad and important class of joint distributions in combinatorics and statistical physics that are constructed over locally tree-like graphs. These models provide examples of measure-preserving actions of free groups, and conversely methods from free-group ergodic theory help to describe their asymptotic behavior. The physics literature predicts novel and consequential phenomena such as shattering and condensation, but only a few special cases have been established rigorously. The project will explore these phenomena using notions and methods from ergodic theory.

por.por_cntn:
This was a theoretical project in the field of pure math called 'ergodic theory'. It can be understood as probing the deepest and most abstract properties of a range of models that appear in probability theory.

Probability theory is applied to describe a huge range of situations in the real world. It does so by setting up and analyzing models that give probability values for all the different possible outcomes in some situations. The world of all probability models is enormous, and a useful analysis generally starts with the more specific properties of a given situation.

Much of the most active recent research on probability models is geared towards data that is intrinsically 'high-dimensional', meaning that a complete outcome involves a very large number of components that interact according to a complicated network of relationships. While the precise network depends on the exact situation, many basic phenomena depend only on broad features of the network, such as (i) for a typical component, how many other components does it interact with directly, and (ii) how many 'short loops' there are among those interactions (such as, A-B-C-A).

Mathematically, we can roughly classify networks according to the answers to such questions, and then explore the consequences for probability models whose structure is chosen to reflect such a network of interactions. Technically, we do this by turning the features of the network into a group of 'associated symmetries' that the models should have.

This project focused on ways of defining and estimating the 'entropy' of such a model, which is our most basic measure of the 'intrinsic randomness' in data generated by the model. Knowing the entropy in the model has a wide range of consequence for its likely behaviour, or for the ease of other kinds of analysis such as 'statistical inference' (the task of tuning some parameters in a model to fit past observations as well as possible in order to improve the model's predictions about future observations). For instance, if a model has very low entropy, then knowing only a few components of an outcome (for example, measuring just a few features of a very complicated data set) can in principle be used to infer many other components. If the entropy is high then this is generally impossible.

Making these relationships precise and rigorous involves a careful combination of approximations, estimates, and calculations using symmetry. In the present project we focused on the very large class of symmetries that have the technical properties of being 'sofic' (which is very common) but not 'amenable' (which is rare, but permits more specialized techniques). This broad class includes the especially important subclass of networks that are 'locally tree-like', which roughly means that each component interacts with several others (specifically, three or more), but there are very few short loops among those interactions.

My students and I contributed to this area by establishing several new theoretical relationships between entropy and other properties of such probability models. These can serve as basic tools for estimation or for the design of inference methods in the future. More recently we have also uncoved some specific examples of probability models with these 'new' symmetry types that exhibit behaviours that are provably impossible in 'older' settings. These help to map the terrain of this large world of complex probability models, providing examples that any subsequent development of the theory must also be able to allow for.

This project supported the thesis work of two PhD students. One has continued in academica, and the other has now transitioned to a specialized job in industry. The research in the project has also informed new graduate-level teaching materials and individual reading courses for several students, both undergraduate and graduate.
